urn:contentItem:5WS5-4N01-F021-637W-00000-00Tap into technology for strong long-term growth2019-08-08T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:29:02ZLexisNexisTap into technology for strong long-term growthZayani Bhatt

Technology has been a major driver of global growth for a number of years. As well as having become a huge part of the way we live and work, it has driven growth in sectors such as healthcare. And this trend looks set to continue for the foreseeable future. "[Tech] stocks are growing faster than the broader market, so if you invest in them you're getting exposure to this growth and companies that are changing the world," says Ryan Hughes, head of active portfolios at broker AJ Bell.

Companies that have changed the way we live include Facebook (FB:NSQ),   Amazon (AMZN:NSQ),   Apple (US:AAPL),   Netflix (US:NFLX) and   Alphabet (US:GOOGL), the company that owns Google. These companies, which are known as the FAANGs, reported good earnings during the last quarter.

Amazon and Alphabet should continue to grow because they are leading research and development in cloud technology. This is the use of remote servers hosted on the internet to store, manage and process data rather than on a local server or personal computer. "Cloud technology has barely penetrated the market so there is tremendous room to grow," says Ben Rogoff, manager of funds including Polar Capital Technology Trust (PCT). "There are really only about five businesses in the world that can do this because it costs billions and is a question of scale. These companies are Amazon, Google,   Microsoft (US:MSFT) and China's   Tencent (Chi:700)."

Adrian Lowcock, head of personal investing at Willis Owen, adds: "As a society we're moving away from consuming things as a product to consuming them as a service instead. For example, we have moved from CDs to streaming services such as   Spotify (US:SPOT)."

Technology is changing sectors such as retail. For example, Amazon fulfilment, a way of getting inventory from the manufacturer directly to the customer, has driven ecommerce, which is still a massive growth trend. And through targeted advertising, Facebook and Instagram have potential as retailers, too. "Thanks to their secular growth they are not dependent on market cycles," adds Mr Rogoff.

The rise in ecommerce has also helped propel the rise of fast, convenient and easy digital payment platforms such as PayPal (US:PYPL). "Every time a dollar goes from being in the shop to online, the payment sector is growing," says Mr Rogoff.

Digital currency may also experience significant growth when Facebook launches its own cryptocurrency, Libra.

Over the much longer term, fund analysts and technology fund managers expect significant growth in robotics and artificial intelligence (AI), although it is still at a nascent stage. Healthcare and the automobile manufacturing sectors are likely to see the most change from the introduction of robotics and AI, which could improve processes and drive down costs. Much of the research and development in this area is being done in Japan.

Tech companies, meanwhile, could benefit from the US Federal Reserve's recent interest rate cut of 0.25 per cent. "Low interest rates can be good for tech because the growth rates that you see in tech continue to look very good compared with the rest of the market," explains Mr Lowcock. "Large companies are not particularly indebted and lower interest rates can make it even easier to clear debt."

And an interest rate cut can make it easier for smaller companies to raise debt via corporate bonds.

There is also potential for an improvement in the income investors get from tech stocks. Last year, US president Donald Trump's one-time repatriation tax of 15.5 per cent on the profits businesses have accumulated overseas helped bring back huge amounts of cash, which over the long term could be used by companies to pay dividends. Apple, for example, had huge amounts of cash and has increased its dividend payments year on year by 13.33 per cent.

There are opportunities outside the US as well. China recently launched the the Shanghai Stock Exchange STAR Market, a trading platform populated by regional tech stocks, formulated along the lines of the US Nasdaq market. China is also home to companies sush as   Alibaba (Chi:241), a multinational conglomerate specialising in ecommerce, retail and internet. Alibaba has also begun to expand into other areas such as food delivery by buying Ele.me, an online food delivery service, which could mean Alibaba's share price grows further.

Tech risks

But the tech sector also faces significant macro risks, such as the uncertainty over how the trade war between the US and China is going to pan out. "[A reason behind] the trade war is Mr Trump's desire to help protect American intellectual property in China," says Gary White, chief investment commentator at Charles Stanley. On 1 August, Mr Trump announced 10 per cent tariffs which will affect a further $300bn (£247bn) of Chinese goods. These tariffs are due to come into effect on 1 September.

Three days later, Beijing responded by allowing the renminbi currency to fall below Rmb7 to the dollar for the first time since the global financial crisis and getting state-owned companies to suspend imports of US agricultural products.

These actions hit equity markets so that on 5 August, the Nasdaq Composite fell 3.5 per cent and the S&P 500 fell 3 per cent.

There are also concerns that the tariffs could affect supply chains. "Semiconductor stocks, for example, have complex supply chains all over the world and Apple relies on these for the supply of iPhone parts," says Mr White.

Big tech companies in the US are under increased scrutiny. At the end of last month, the US Department of Justice announced a broad antitrust investigation into whether leading online platforms are unfairly restricting competition. "This could increase overheads if they have to operate in a more heavily regulated environment than they have done until now," says Mr Hughes.

And Facebook has been fined $5bn because the US consumer protection agency, The Federal Trade Commission, discovered data privacy violations following the leak of up to 87m users' information through Facebook to Cambridge Analytica.

Another major risk is slowing global growth. Mr Hughes thinks that the Federal Reserve's interest rate cut indicates that there is a slowdown, but as it only cut US interest rates by 0.25 per cent it suggests that it is not expecting a recession imminently. "However, we are in the longest period of expansion that we've seen, so I would say we're in the late end of the cycle," adds Mr Hughes.

Valuations of tech stocks also look high. "Despite what looks like a sharp fall, the tech market is only really back to where it was two or three months ago, so not much has changed," says Mr Hughes.

And the tech sector is more volatile than many other equity sectors because many companies in this area fail, and dominant players can be overthrown by disrupters.

The dominance of the FAANG stocks means that global growth funds and US equity funds - as well as technology funds - are likely to have exposure to them. This means that if you add a technology fund to your portfolio you could unintentionally have more exposure to these companies than you intended. To avoid this, before you invest in a fund check what holdings it has. You can see what a fund's 10 largest holdings are on its monthly fact sheet or on data websites such as morningstar.co.uk.

Mr Hughes also suggests investors understand a manager's investment style to get an idea of what the fund they run might typically invest in.

Mr Hughes says that investors with less investment knowledge and who do not have a very high risk appetite should get exposure to technology shares via a global equities fund that invests across various sectors, so is potentially less volatile than a tech fund. Investors with more knowledge and a higher risk appetite could consider a US equities fund [read more on these in the big theme of the 26 July issue].

Investors with a high risk appetite and long-term investment horizon could consider a technology fund. However, Mr Lowcock suggests that no investor allocate more than 2 to 3 per cent of their portfolio to technology funds so that their overall portfolio, which is also likely to include global and US funds, would have at most an allocation of 5 per cent to 6 per cent to technology shares

Fund for tech exposure

Investors who want exposure to technology stocks but do not have a high enough risk appetite to invest in a technology fund could could consider Baillie Gifford Global Discovery (GB0006059330). This fund aims for growth over the long term, and is managed by Douglas Brodie, and deputy managers Svetlana Viteva and Luke Ward. They invest the fund in companies with significant growth prospects, in particular those in industries with the potential for structural change and innovation.

However, this fund is by no means low risk as its managers say their holdings could have a wide range of potential outcomes and it has a bias to smaller companies. "It is at the risky growth end of the market, but is one way to get exposure to some of the trends going on," says Mr Lowcock.

The fund's managers aim for the fund to be diverse and get exposure to technology via companies that are not necessarily in the tech sector, such as UK-listed home delivery service Ocado (OCDO) and healthcare companies. Its largest holding is   LendingTree (US:TREE), an online lending platform in the US.

The fund had 22 per cent of its assets in technology shares at the end of June.

Baillie Gifford Global Discovery has beaten its benchmark, the S&P Global Small Cap index over one, three and five years.

For exposure to tech stocks via a potentially less volatile fund, options include Artemis Global Select (GB00B568S201), which had 21 per cent of it assets in this sector as of 28 June. Its largest holdings include Microsoft. But this fund can also have up to 20 per cent of its assets in cash to help reduce capital loss when markets fall.

The fund has been managed by Simon Edelsten, Alex Illingworth and Rosanna Burcheri since 2011. They aim for growth by investing in what they consider to be high-quality stocks, so look for companies with strong market positions and balance sheets, and sustainable pricing power. They focus on companies that have the strength and financial resources for long-term growth, regardless of the short-term economic environment or current share price.

They have a disciplined approach to valuation, so they only invest in shares when they believe the time and price are right.

If you want to invest in tech shares via a passive fund, Patrick Connolly, chartered financial planner at Chase de Vere, suggests   L&G Global Technology Index (GB00B0CNhl3), a cheaper option with an ongoing charge of only 0.32 per cent. The fund tracks FTSE World Technology Index and its 10 biggest holdings include large blue-chips such as Apple, Alphabet, Microsoft and   Oracle (US:ORCL). However, because it is a passive fund it does not offer the prospect of beating this index and in times of volatility, as are to be expected with tech stocks, it will mirror the falls in the index.

Active technology fund options include Polar Capital Global Technology (IE00B42W4J83), run by a nine-strong team led by Nick Evans and Mr Rogoff. "They're very good, very experienced tech investors," says Mr Lowcock. "And they've got a very disciplined process for stockpicking."

The fund's largest holdings include Alibaba and Advanced Micro Devices (US:AMD), an American multinational semiconductor company.

The fund aims for long-term capital appreciation by investing in a globally diversified portfolio of technology companies. Its investment team identifies growth trends and selects stocks within those trends.

The fund has performed very well beating MSCI AWCI Information Technology index over one, three, five and 10 years.

All of these funds should be held for at least five years and the two technology funds for longer to give you enough time to recover from any steep falls in their value.

urn:contentItem:5WSB-4SR1-JCBW-N4BB-00000-00Tap into technology for strong long-term growth;Technology funds have strong growth potential, but are also very high risk2019-08-09T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:29:02ZLexisNexisNEWSPg. 43,44Tap into technology for strong long-term growthTechnology funds have strong growth potential, but are also very high risk

ZAYANI BHATT Technology has been a major driver of global growth for a number of years. As well as having become a huge part of the way we live and work, it has driven growth in sectors such as healthcare. And this trend looks set to continue for the foreseeable future. "[Tech] stocks are growing faster than the broader market, so if you invest in them you're getting exposure to this growth and companies that are changing the world," says Ryan Hughes, head of active portfolios at broker AJ Bell.

Companies that have changed the way we live include Facebook (US:FB), Amazon (US:AMZN), Apple (US:AAPL), Netflix (US:NFLX) and Alphabet (US:GOOGL), the company that owns Google. These companies, which are known as the FAANGs, reported good earnings in the last quarter.

Amazon and Alphabet should continue to grow because they are leading research and development in cloud technology. This is the use of remote servers hosted on the internet to store, manage and process data rather than on a local server or personal computer. "Cloud technology has barely penetrated the market so there is tremendous room to grow," says Ben Rogoff, manager of funds including Polar Capital Technology Trust (PCT). "There are really only about five businesses in the world that can do this because it costs billions and is a question of scale. These companies are Amazon, Google, Microsoft (US:MSFT) and China's Tencent (Chi:700)."

Adrian Lowcock, head of personal investing at Willis Owen, adds: "As a society we're moving away from consuming things as a product to consuming them as a service instead. For example, we have moved from CDs to streaming services such as Spotify (US:SPOT)."

Technology is changing sectors such as retail. For example, Amazon fulfilment, a way of getting inventory from the manufacturer directly to the customer, has driven ecommerce, which is still a massive growth trend. And through targeted advertising, Facebook and Instagram have potential as retailers, too. "Thanks to their secular growth they are not dependent on market cycles," adds Mr Rogoff.

The rise in ecommerce has also helped propel the rise of fast, convenient and easy digital payment platforms such as PayPal (US:PYPL). "Every time a dollar goes from being in the shop to online, the payment sector is growing," says Mr Rogoff.

Digital currency may also experience significant growth when Facebook launches its own cryptocurrency, Libra.

Over the much longer term, fund analysts and technology fund managers expect significant growth in robotics and artificial intelligence (AI), although it is still at a nascent stage. Healthcare and the automobile manufacturing sectors are likely to see the most change from the introduction of robotics and AI, which could improve processes and drive down costs. Much of the research and development in this area is being done in Japan.

Tech companies, meanwhile, could benefit from the US Federal Reserve's recent interest rate cut of 0.25 per cent. "Low interest rates can be good for tech because the growth rates that you see in tech continue to look very good compared with the rest of the market," explains Mr Lowcock. "Large companies are not particularly indebted and lower interest rates can make it even easier to clear debt."

And an interest rate cut can make it easier for smaller companies to raise debt via corporate bonds.

There is also potential for an improvement in the income investors get from tech stocks. Last year, US president Donald Trump's onetime repatriation tax of 15.5 per cent on the profits businesses have accumulated overseas helped bring back huge amounts of cash, which over the long term could be used by companies to pay dividends. Apple, for example, had huge amounts of cash and has increased its dividend payments year on year by 13.33 per cent.

There are opportunities outside the US as well. China recently launched the Shanghai Stock Exchange STAR Market, a trading platform populated by regional tech stocks, formulated along the lines of the US Nasdaq market. China is also home to companies such as Alibaba (Chi:241), a multinational conglomerate specialising in ecommerce, retail and internet. Alibaba has also begun to expand into other areas such as food delivery by buying Ele.me, an online food delivery service, which could mean Alibaba's share price grows further.

Tech risks But the tech sector also faces significant macro risks, such as the uncertainty over how the trade war between the US and China is going to pan out. "[A reason behind] the trade war is Mr Trump's desire to help protect American intellectual property in China," says Gary White, chief investment commentator at Charles Stanley. On 1 August, Mr Trump announced 10 per cent tariffs which will affect a further $300bn (£247bn) of Chinese goods. These tariffs are due to come into effect on 1 September.

Three days later, Beijing responded by allowing the renminbi currency to fall below Rmb7 to the dollar for the first time since the global financial crisis and getting stateowned companies to suspend imports of US agricultural products.

These actions hit equity markets so that on 5 August, the Nasdaq Composite fell 3.5 per cent and the S&P 500 fell 3 per cent.

There are also concerns that the tariffs could affect supply chains. "Semiconductor stocks, for example, have complex supply chains all over the world and Apple relies on these for the supply of iPhone parts," says Mr White.

Big tech companies in the US are under increased scrutiny. At the end of last month, the US Department of Justice announced a broad antitrust investigation into whether leading online platforms are unfairly restricting competition. "This could increase overheads if they have to operate in a more heavily regulated environment than they have done until now," says Mr Hughes.

And Facebook has been fined $5bn because the US consumer protection agency, The Federal Trade Commission, discovered data privacy violations following the leak of up to 87m users' information through Facebook to Cambridge Analytica.

Another major risk is slowing global growth. Mr Hughes thinks that the Federal Reserve's interest rate cut indicates that there is a slowdown, but as it only cut US interest rates by 0.25 per cent it suggests that it is not expecting a recession imminently. "However, we are in the longest period of expansion that we've seen, so I would say we're in the late end of the cycle," adds Mr Hughes.

Valuations of tech stocks also look high.

"Despite what looks like a sharp fall, the tech market is only really back to where it was two or three months ago, so not much has changed," says Mr Hughes.

And the tech sector is more volatile than many other equity sectors because many companies in this area fail, and dominant players can be overthrown by disrupters.

The dominance of the FAANG stocks means that global growth funds and US equity funds - as well as technology funds - are likely to have exposure to them. This means that if you add a technology fund to your portfolio you could unintentionally have more exposure to these companies than you intended. To avoid this, before you invest in a fund check what holdings it has. You can see what a fund's 10 largest holdings are on its monthly fact sheet or on data websites such as www.morningstar.co.uk.

Mr Hughes also suggests investors understand a manager's investment style to get an idea of what the fund they run might typically invest in.

Mr Hughes says that investors with less investment knowledge and who do not have a very high-risk appetite should get exposure to technology shares via a global equities fund that invests across various sectors, so is potentially less volatile than a tech fund. Investors with more knowledge and a higher risk appetite could consider a US equities fund [read more on these in the big theme of the 26 July issue].

Investors with a high risk appetite and long-term investment horizon could consider a technology fund. However, Mr Lowcock suggests that no investor allocate more than 2 to 3 per cent of their portfolio to technology funds, so that their overall portfolio, which is also likely to include global and US funds, would have at most an allocation of 5 per cent to 6 per cent to technology shares.

Fund for tech exposure Investors who want exposure to technology stocks but do not have a high enough risk appetite to invest in a technology fund could consider Baillie Gifford Global Discovery (GB0006059330). This fund aims for growth over the long term, and is managed by Douglas Brodie, and deputy managers Svetlana Viteva and Luke Ward. They invest the fund in companies with significant growth prospects, in particular those in industries with the potential for structural change and innovation.

However, this fund is by no means low risk as its managers say their holdings could have a wide range of potential outcomes and it has a bias to smaller companies. "It is at the risky growth end of the market, but is one way to get exposure to some of the trends going on," says Mr Lowcock.

'The tech sector is more volatile than many other equity sectors because many companies in this area fail, and dominant players can be overthrown by disrupters' The fund's managers aim for the fund to be diverse and get exposure to technology via companies that are not necessarily in the tech sector, such as UK-listed home delivery service Ocado (OCDO) and healthcare companies. Its largest holding is LendingTree (US:TREE), an online lending platform in the US.

The fund had 22 per cent of its assets in technology shares at the end of June.

Baillie Gifford Global Discovery has beaten its benchmark, the S&P Global Small Cap index over one, three and five years.

For exposure to tech stocks via a potentially less volatile fund, options include Artemis Global Select (GB00B568S201), which had 21 per cent of it assets in this sector as of 28 June. Its largest holdings include Microsoft. But this fund can also have up to 20 per cent of its assets in cash to help reduce capital loss when markets fall.

The fund has been managed by Simon Edelsten, Alex Illingworth and Rosanna Burcheri since 2011. They aim for growth by investing in what they consider to be high-quality stocks, so look for companies with strong market positions and balance sheets, and sustainable pricing power. They focus on companies that have the strength and financial resources for longterm growth, regardless of the short-term economic environment or share price.

They have a disciplined approach to valuation, so they only invest in shares when they believe the time and price are right.

If you want to invest in tech shares via a passive fund, Patrick Connolly, chartered financial planner at Chase de Vere, suggests L&G Global Technology Index (GB00B0CNH163), a cheaper option with an ongoing charge of only 0.32 per cent. The fund tracks FTSE World Technology Index and its 10 biggest holdings include large blue-chips such as Apple, Alphabet, Microsoft and Oracle (US:ORCL). However, because it is a passive fund it does not offer the prospect of beating this index and in times of volatility, as are to be expected with tech stocks, it will mirror the falls in the index.

Active technology fund options include Polar Capital Global Technology (IE00B42W4J83), run by a nine-strong team led by Nick Evans and Mr Rogoff. "They're very good, very experienced tech investors," says Mr Lowcock. "And they've got a very disciplined process for stockpicking."

The fund's largest holdings include Alibaba and Advanced Micro Devices (US:AMD), an American multinational semiconductor company.

The fund aims for long-term capital appreciation by investing in a globally diversified portfolio of technology companies. Its investment team identifies growth trends and selects stocks within those trends.

The fund has performed very well, beating MSCI AWCI Information Technology index over one, three, five and 10 years.

All of these funds should be held for at least five years and the two technology funds for longer to give you enough time to recover from any steep falls in their value.

urn:contentItem:5Y6N-3NP1-JBFS-C2GS-00000-00Tapping tech giants to pay their own way;Culver City may make Amazon, Apple cover more costs of growth.2020-02-14T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:29:02ZLexisNexisMAIN NEWSEntertainment DeskPart APg. 1Tapping tech giants to pay their own wayCulver City may make Amazon, Apple cover more costs of growth.Wendy Lee

Inside the 8-year-old light rail station, Culver City Mayor Meghan Sahli-Wells gazed at the bustling skyline of this once sleepy Westside suburb known for movie studios, auto repair shops and affordable single-story homes for aerospace workers.

Everything has changed for this city of 39,000 people. The mayor pointed to the north, where a five-story building with red trim is being constructed -- a future home for HBO's West Coast headquarters.

To the southwest, the historic Culver Studios -- home to such movie productions as "Gone With the Wind" and "Citizen Kane" -- has been transformed by Amazon Studios since it started leasing space there in 2017. "All of it is Amazon," she said, scanning construction several blocks away.

"Let's face it. We're kind of hot right now," Sahli-Wells said. "There are a lot of major companies that are locating in Culver City. Especially as we welcome some of the wealthiest corporations on the planet, it would be appropriate to ensure that all businesses are paying their fair share."

Culver City has become one of the fastest-growing digital media hubs in Southern California as Amazon, Apple, China-owned TikTok and other firms have expanded into the area, drawn to its location and movie history. The influx has brought thousands of new jobs to the city but also caused some growing pains. Now, Culver City officials are considering a tactic that Silicon Valley cities have pursued: raising business taxes to help manage the inevitable costs of growth.

If history is any guide, such a move could create tensions between the city and the towering tech giants reshaping it. Amazon and Apple have occasionally clashed with cities in other areas over proposed tax hikes or policies deemed unfriendly to their interests.

Colin Diaz, president of the Culver City Chamber of Commerce, said his members, which include Amazon and Apple, are "open to discussion," but warned that some businesses may be forced to move.

"It will definitely cause businesses to leave," Diaz said. "There would be a noticeable impact."

Under the current tax, many businesses pay 0.1% to 0.3% of their gross receipts (depending on the industry type), while some companies pay a flat fee.

Discussions are in the early stages, however, and any increase would have to be approved by a majority of the council and by residents in a ballot measure.

The city hasn't updated the tax since 1965 and has generated significantly less revenue than L.A., Beverly Hills and Santa Monica. A city committee has weighed various models for increasing business tax revenue, including one that would raise as much as $33 million annually, up from $12 million, according to a presentation obtained by The Times . That hike, if implemented, would put Culver City's rates in line with those of Santa Monica. On Wednesday night, a tax advisory group proposed a nearly $10-million increase.

Culver City's leaders say the extra money is necessary because the city faces a projected $3-million operating deficit in its general fund starting in fiscal year 2023, mainly because of rising pension costs. By fiscal year 2029, that deficit is expected to grow to $6.8 million.

The financial crunch comes as the city must boost its housing supply to meet state guidelines. The city will need to accommodate 3,300 new homes over the next nine years. But that may not be enough to handle a population influx from more than 7,300 new jobs the city expects to bring in by 2022.

TikTok says it could grow to about 1,000 people. Amazon's staff is estimated to be 2,400 during 2021; HBO is expected to have 750 employees, and Apple will employ about 1,595 once construction of its new building is completed, according to Culver City estimates .

"The real concern for Culver City, in this case, is that in many ways they've authorized these mixed-use developments ... without really understanding the bigger impact it would have on the city and the limits to the capacity of the train station, so now they're in this trap," said Kevin Klowden, executive director for the Milken Institute's Center for Regional Economics and California Center.

Similar pressures have flared up in Seattle and Silicon Valley, where rapid growth by technology companies has prompted cities to consider raising taxes to help pay for the growing demand on services.

While tech companies have been blamed for the surge in high-paying jobs that have driven up rents, cities have also been criticized for not prioritizing enough housing. In the San Francisco Bay Area, home prices and apartment rents have soared to the highest in the country, forcing some to live in their cars or park RVs on city streets.

"We've gleaned lessons from big tech companies in other cities, and we want to make sure that we're learning those lessons and we're moving forward in a positive and a productive way," Sahli-Wells said.

In 2018, residents of Google's hometown, Mountain View, passed a measure to dramatically increase the city's typical $30 business license fee. The new fee, which is being phased in, would charge more for larger businesses based on employee headcount. For Google, the city's largest employer with more than 25,400 workers, that will mean paying $3.6 million starting in 2022, money that the city says will go toward its transportation projects.

"Mountain View has been blessed and cursed with the rapid growth of employment," said Lenny Siegel, Mountain View's former mayor, who led the effort to increase the fee. "We really can't handle much more employees given our housing and transportation situation. We already have too much."

In recent years, large tech companies have pushed back on cities taxing them more based on the number of employees. In 2018, Amazon voiced its disapproval on a headcount tax in Seattle, suspending its plans to build an office tower until after the City Council's vote. The council ended up approving the tax, only to repeal it shortly afterward.

In Apple's hometown of Cupertino, city leaders in 2016 and 2018 explored a headcount tax only to have those efforts squashed by fierce opposition from business groups backed by Apple. Both Apple and Google have supported plans to address the Bay Area's housing crisis.

"It's not our taxes or regulation that is a threat to the companies but their own growth," said Siegel, who grew up in Culver City. "The companies are responsible for helping the community handle their growth."

Culver City has a storied history in moviemaking. Its founder, Harry Culver, encouraged filmmaker Thomas Ince to move his studio from the beach to Culver City, which was incorporated in 1917. The city became known as "the Heart of Screenland," where movies such as "E.T. the Extra-Terrestrial" and "The Wizard of Oz" were filmed.

Today, it is home to Sony Pictures Entertainment, the city's largest employer with about 3,500 workers. But the city became more of a hub for streaming services when Amazon Studios moved into the historic Culver Studios in 2017, with plans to lease 530,000 square feet of the campus. Amazon also rents 75,000 square feet at the Culver Steps across the street.

The company was drawn to Culver City's long history and legacy of moviemaking, said Albert Cheng, Amazon Studios' chief operating officer.

"Having our home here in Culver Studios represents what we see as our investment in this space, which is honoring (and building on) the legacy of the amazing history of what the studio has, (with) over 100 years of movie and television production ... and creating a foundation on which we can take the industry to the future," Cheng said.

Other factors included the city's central location, making it easier for employees to access, as well as its proximity to the airport and Amazon Studios partners, such as agencies in Beverly Hills, Cheng said.

Cheng declined to comment on the city exploring an increase in the business tax. "The City Council will do what it's going to do," he said.

Apple expanded to Culver City with the 2014 purchase of streaming music firm Beats, which already had an office there. Since then, Apple has leased space at One Culver and the Hayden Tract; it will eventually expand into a new office on Washington Boulevard.

Next year, HBO's West Coast office will move from Santa Monica to Culver City's Ivy Station, inside a 240,000-square-foot space.

HBO, Apple, TikTok and Sony declined to comment for this article.

The influx of Apple, Amazon, and other tech and media companies has been a boon to local restaurants and other small businesses.

Adam Guttentag, owner of Harajuku Taproom, said his pub on Sepulveda Boulevard has seen a roughly 20% increase in sales over last year, with more companies contacting him for holiday parties and happy hours. He declined to disclose sales figures.

"Overall, the development is a positive thing," Guttentag said. "(It's) a lot of good jobs, people with good disposable income. Those are people who enjoy fun dining experiences, and those are all good customers for us."

But the demand for office space from tech and media companies has driven up rents in Culver City at a faster pace than the rest of the L.A. metro market. Since the fourth quarter of 2010, rents for office space have increased 56% in Culver City, compared with 45% for L.A. County during the same period, according to CoStar Group, which tracks real estate trends.

Rising rents could make it harder for small businesses to absorb an increase in business taxes, forcing some to lay off workers or leave the area, said Diaz of the Culver City Chamber, which has representatives from Apple and Amazon on its board.

He said city businesses already contribute heavily to the city's general fund.

"We're not against the conversation of looking at a business license tax increase," Diaz said. "We also would want there to be some restraint as far as spending."

Ryan Patap, director of market analytics for CoStar Group, doesn't think an increase in Culver City's business tax will turn away large employers, because they want to be closer to where the talent is.

"It doesn't seem to me that it would upend fundamentals and change people's decision-making," Patap said.

Sahli-Wells hasn't said how much she wants to see the tax raised. That amount could depend on whether residents support a March ballot measure that extends a 0.5% sales tax until 2033.

"It's a moment of growth -- that's what is happening right now," Sahli-Wells said. "I don't know how long it is going to last. I just want to make sure it goes smoothly."

Sushma Ramachandran Senior Financial Journalist The chief executives of the world’s four most powerful tech companies were grilled recently by the US lawmakers on a wide range of issues, ranging from competition to alleged theft of data by China. Apple, Facebook, Google’s parent company Alphabet and Amazon had to face a barrage of questions that could ultimately decide the future course of monopoly laws in the US. Simultaneously, Australia has laid down regulations to ensure that tech giants will have to pay for the use of news from media outlets. Both developments are of immense relevance in India as these same companies dominate the digital arena here. Even as Big Tech is facing potential curbs, these entities are also seeing a huge surge in growth and profitability — at a time when the global economy is facing severe disruptions owing to the pandemic. Amazon’s profits, for instance, rose by 40 per cent in the April-June quarter. Over the same period, Facebook’s profits spiked by an unreal 98 per cent, while Apple recorded a 12 per cent growth. Alphabet was relatively a laggard with three per cent profit, but revenue increased by 13 per cent. In contrast, the world economy is set to contract by as much as five per cent during 2020. The divergence is because the consumption of online content has risen exponentially while the overall demand for other products has fallen precipitously. Amazon has benefited not just from its Prime Video content but also from the ease of online deliveries at a time when buying from brick and mortar retail outlets has slowed down. Other streaming and OTT platforms have also got a boost globally and in this country. This has altered the established advertising-cum-subscription model, with ad revenues dipping and subscribers rapidly growing. Some media reports say subscribers have risen by as much as 60 per cent ever since the pandemic began. The top player in the Indian market currently is the Disney-Hotstar brand with an estimated eight million subscribers followed by Amazon Prime, SonyLiv, Netflix and Voot as well as a host of others. The other gainers in the digital space are gaming apps which have seen an enormous growth during the lockdown period. Fantasy sports apps are expected to see a spurt as soon as the IPL is revived. The digital arena, thus, continues to thrive at a time when the global Covid outbreak has threatened the very existence of traditional businesses. A parallel occurrence to the growth of tech giants has been a widening of the digital divide in this country. This has followed a shift to online education after the schools closed down all over the country since the lockdown was imposed at the end of March. Children with access to devices like smartphones, tablets, computers or even televisions, have been able to utilise the new mode of teaching. Others, including the urban poor and those in rural areas, have simply been left rudderless without any teaching facilities for months on end now. Tragic stories have surfaced of children and even parents committing suicide because they could not afford to buy smartphones. Voluntary organisations and individuals have begun drives to provide computers and televisions to children in many parts of the country. An initiative has even been launched to provide used devices to the needy students. The fact is that this is just not enough to cover the millions of children who need to use online education. Official data says there are over 35 crore students in the country, but no data is available to show how many have access to digital devices or the Internet. A study done by an NGO of over 40,000 children, covering 23 states in April, found that about 56 per cent children did not have smartphones. Apart from the devices, the other issue was connectivity problems with the Internet. The Kerala government has tried to overcome this problem by offering classes on television. But this approach has a lacuna as there is no possibility of an interaction with the students. With online education likely to remain a reality for some more time, it is time to adopt innovative solutions to ensure that millions of children do not lag behind their more affluent peers. One way could be to copy the model of universal healthcare and adopt the slogan of universal smartphones for schoolchildren. Indigenously made smartphones or tablets could be mass produced and provided to all students of government schools. This would not only provide students with the much-needed devices, but also give a fillip to indigenous smartphone production, a cause close to this government’s heart. But this could take a while and fail to solve the immediate crisis facing the country’s students. Another option could be to open the schools gradually, keeping social distancing norms in place. And finally, the third and most attractive option could be to tap the deep pockets of the tech giants that are raking in profits right now during the pandemic. Let them use their enormous resources to provide tech-based solutions to the millions of underprivileged children who cannot access any form of education right now. The fact is, unless the digital divide is bridged, there will be a long-term, adverse impact on these young students. The prosperity of the tech giants is growing owing to their access to the Indian market. It is thus entirely in the fitness of things that they join hands with policymakers here to provide a concrete solution to the digital divide at this critical juncture. The government needs to open a dialogue with Big Tech companies and try to solve this problem with their help. Otherwise, the prolonged break in the educational process could have profound ramifications for the youth of the country.

1-2) Mark Zuckerberg is CEO of Facebook. Andreas Mundt is Germany's top antitrust official.

LONDON - Germany's top antitrust enforcer recently asked a room full of lawyers, academics and regulators to imagine a wall filled with their personal information collected by Facebook and Google. He told them to picture it stocked with their data broken up into categories such as finances, location, relationships and hobbies. "That is you," Andres Mundt said. "And I promise you this wall knows you better than your wife."

Few listened to Mundt when, a few years ago, he began raising alarms about the data collected by the tech giants. But in February, his agency ruled that Facebook had broken the country's law and demanded that the company stop automatically sharing data among the services it owns, such as Instagram and WhatsApp, or websites that use its "like" and "share" buttons. It was the first such ruling in Europe, putting in practice ideas that had never fully escaped academic and think tank debates. As U.S. regulators and lawmakers intensify their scrutiny of Big Tech, there is a lot of discussion about whether or how they could accuse the companies of violating antitrust law. Often, regulators look to whether a company is causing consumer harm - a standard that can be hard to prove when a service is free. The response from Mundt is simple. The only way to take on Facebook and some of its peers is to attack what they value most: data. He argues that the companies are so dominant in their core businesses that consumers, if they want to search the internet or be on social media, have no choice but to share their personal data. The data then strengthens the tech companies' position over rivals even more - and therefore is anticompetitive, Mundt said. After the Facebook ruling, Mundt received calls from regulators and lawyers around the world to discuss the idea. He helped organize a meeting of fellow antitrust officials in Colombia, where they spent four days discussing tech regulation. Joseph Simons, chairman of the Federal Trade Commission, and Makan Delrahim, head of the Justice Department antitrust division, were among those attending. "The German authority is way out in front here and in a real sense the leading antitrust authority in the world with respect to these technology issues," said Thomas Vinje, partner at the Clifford Chance law firm in Brussels and a veteran of tech industry antitrust battles involving Microsoft and Google. Online platforms constantly collect data on users: what is clicked on, how fast a person scrolls past a post, what video a person stops to watch. The information helps a company such as Facebook infer characteristics about interests, personal connections and financial demographics to better target advertising, or train machine-learning algorithms that can be used for future products. It is an extraordinarily lucrative business model. Facebook made $55 billion from advertising last year, while Google's ad sales totaled $116 billion. What's distressing to regulators is the lack of new competitors, a trend Mundt attributes to a company's access to data and plentiful financial resources. He said Facebook controls more than 95 percent of the social networking market in Germany. Without competition, the network unfairly forces people to make an all-or-nothing choice between agreeing to unlimited data collection or not using Facebook at all. Mundt contends that Facebook and other tech giants don't need to be broken up, as Sen. Elizabeth Warren and others have suggested. Instead, he thinks governments should limit their ability to collect data. The approach can have an effect similar to a breakup by isolating a company's different services. "The business model is to gather and process data, full stop. There is nothing else," Mundt said. "If they don't have data, they can have 10,000 very intelligent engineers who tell you what you can make out of data, but without the data you don't make anything." Facebook is appealing the German decision, arguing that it was transparent with users about how data is collected. The social network argues that its use of data helps improve the service and that German regulators singled it out for practices common across the internet.

urn:contentItem:5W8C-0B51-DXH2-60G1-00000-00Tariff Battle; Wal-Mart's College Plan; U.S. Tech Giants Facing Probes; Stock Surge; President Trump Continues Great Britain Visit2019-06-04T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:29:02ZLexisNexisYOUR WORLD WITH NEIL CAVUTO4:00 PM ESTLee Carter, Scott Martin, Cathy Areu, Noelle Nikpour, George SeayNEWSInternational060401cb.140Tariff Battle; Wal-Mart's College Plan; U.S. Tech Giants Facing Probes; Stock Surge; President Trump Continues Great Britain VisitDonna Brazile, Kat Timpf, Andrew Napolitano, Jackie DeAngelis, John Roberts, Susan Li, Neil Cavuto

NEIL CAVUTO, FOX NEWS ANCHOR: All right, the royal dinner going on right now as we speak at the Winfield House, the residence of the ambassador, the American ambassador to Great Britain.

The president exchanging the courtesy that the Brits afforded him with a dinner of his own to host the key British players. There is a possibility in a little bit we could be hearing from individual participants, maybe the president a little bit later in the dinner.

But the pool spray that they like to call it of the room is done. And, of course, the feast is on.

But the feast was on at the corner of Wall and Broad? See what I did there. The feast was on the corner of Wall and Broad.

Welcome, everybody. I'm Neil Cavuto.

So let's talk about stocks. Let's talk about the president, because what's going on over here is something that was really reflective of what was going on over there, partly, the president not backing down on his trade fight with Mexico now, amid tensions that are still high with China.

But those two were linked by the Federal Reserve, and the chairman, Jerome Powell, saying that the Central Bank is prepared to act to protect the economy if, in fact, things get much worse on the trade front, in other words, if things slow down.

The markets immediately pounced on that as a sign that the Fed has the president's back and has our back just in case things slip, slide away on the trade front, the Dow up about 511 points today. The Nasdaq, which had entered a correction territory, down about 10 percent, or a little bit more from its highs, coming back today.

We have got a lot going on here. We have got FOX team coverage with John Roberts in London, where the president is not letting Mexico off the hook. We have also got FOX Business Network's Susan Li on a Fed chief who doesn't want to be on the hook.

We begin with John.

Hey, John.

JOHN ROBERTS, FOX NEWS CHIEF WHITE HOUSE CORRESPONDENT: Hey. Good evening to you, Neil.

The stock market didn't seem to care a whole lot about what the president said regarding Mexico. We should point out that one of the guests at that dinner at the ambassador's residence at Winfield House has got an early flight tomorrow morning.

Secretary of State Mike Pompeo will be leaving it first light head back to the United States because he will be leading negotiations with the Mexican delegation in Washington, D.C., to see if they will do something, if they're willing to do something more to stop Central American migrants from moving through Mexico toward the U.S. border.

The president today, seemingly unimpressed with recent Mexican claims that they have stepped up apprehensions and deportations of Central American migrants who are in Mexico illegally, the president suggesting that those tariffs that are scheduled to go into effect on Monday at 5 percent are going to go into effect.

And the president also dismissing some talk about some Republicans in Congress that they may move to block those tariffs before they go into effect. Listen to what the president said earlier today.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

DONALD TRUMP, PRESIDENT OF THE UNITED STATES: I don't think they will do that. I think, if they do, it's foolish. There's nothing more important than borders. I have had tremendous Republican support.

And, as you know, Mexico called. They want to meet. They're going to meet on Wednesday. Secretary Pompeo is going to be at the meeting, along with a few others that are very good at this. And we are going to see if we can do something. But I think it's more likely that the tariffs go on. And we will probably be talking during the time that the tariffs are on and they're going to be paid.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

ROBERTS: You know, one of the big issues that was going on in talks between the United States and Britain, particularly this morning, when the president was sitting down with Theresa May, was Britain's plans to use Huawei equipment made in China as part of its new 5G system.

Originally, Britain wanted to use Huawei equipment in its 5G core, because basically they're selling it for pennies on the dollar against equipment from other countries. And there's a reason for that, many American officials believe, because China wants to get into the core of the new 5G systems because everything that flows through there can be sucked out and sent back to China.

So I'm told by national security officials that they have convinced Britain not to use Huawei in the core. But Britain, not wanting to really upset China, still wanted to use some Huawei equipment. But the president suggesting at the press conference with Theresa May earlier today that they do have an agreement on Huawei, though he wouldn't say exactly what it was.

Listen here.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

TRUMP: We're going to have absolutely an agreement on Huawei and everything else. We have an incredible intelligence relationship and we will be able to work out any differences. I think we're not going to have -- but we did discuss it. I see absolutely no limitations. We have never had limitations.

This is a truly great ally and partner, and we will have no problem with that.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

ROBERTS: And British officials suggest that there is some sort of an agreement. They didn't want to talk to us about the details before it goes to Parliament.

But the president was suggesting that, if the Britain was to use 5G equipment from Huawei in their systems, that that might kind of upset the apple cart in terms of intelligence-sharing with the United States. And that's clearly something that Britain doesn't want to broach -- Neil.

CAVUTO: All right, John Roberts traveling with the president in London right now.

Now, you might hear this back and forth on trade, and now the issues with the Mexicans and the Chinese and the slowdown that could follow. Well, why would start to rise in that environment? Precisely because the Federal Reserve said it has everybody's back in case that does happen.

To Susan Li on that.

Hey, Susan.

SUSAN LI, FOX NEWS CORRESPONDENT: Yes, you're exactly right, Neil, so the Federal Reserve providing cover today, telling the markets if trade wars hurt economic growth, we can adjust and cut interest rates, and that sent the stock market into rally mode.

Wall Street pricing in a near certainty that interest rates will be cut this year. That's close to 100 percent, the probability sitting at 97 percent. Big tech names were the main drags yesterday on concerns they will be broken up or at least investigated over antitrust concerns, coming back today, so recovery for Amazon, Google, parent to Alphabet, as well as, as you see, Apple, Netflix and Microsoft.

And when these heavyweight stocks move, they tend to take the broader markets along with them. Now, we do have the Mexican foreign minister, along with the Mexican economic minister, in Washington, D.C., right now. They are meeting with House Speaker Nancy Pelosi, but the Mexican side have threatened to retaliate if President Trump does go through with these tariffs on all Mexican goods that come into the U.S.

And President Trump did say this morning in that London press conference that tariffs will likely go up. Now, will that impact the U.S. economy? That really depends on how long tariffs stay on and how high they eventually get -- Neil.

CAVUTO: All right, Susan, thank you very, very much.

With the Dow surge today, about 512.5 points, that is the best performance of the year for the Dow on this, after getting just clubbed on concerns about trade.

So what are we really looking at here?

Let's get the read from George Seay of Annandale Capital. He's the CEO there. We have also got Jackie DeAngelis with us, of course, FOX Business Network.

Jackie, a weird reaction, and then you can understand, yes, if rates come down, that will weather this. But obviously the Fed is prepared for something.

JACKIE DEANGELIS, FOX BUSINESS CORRESPONDENT: Well, the Fed changed the game today, Neil, I mean, basically coming out and telling President Trump that he's got their back and that a rate cut is definitely in the cards.

And that's something that investors wanted to hear. They thought it was on the table, but they didn't get the confidence or the language from the Fed that they wanted to hear. Today, that's what they got. So nothing's changed in terms of trade. In fact, the president said, come Monday, those 5 percent tariffs on Mexico will probably go into place.

That's what he told us today. But the market feels more confident that there's support for economic growth and that Jerome Powell is going to step up and do the right thing.

He made two mistakes. Basically, there was a communication mistake at the end of last year. He corrected that. Correcting the policy mistake, as the market sees it, would be implementing a cut.

CAVUTO: Right.

You know, the president criticized the rate hikes, as you know, George, saying that they were a little bit more than was needed. The latest talk is that maybe we could unwind two of the 10 rate hikes we have seen since this tightening cycle started with the former Federal Reserve chief beforehand.

Now I'm wondering where this goes, because you could also interpret from that the Fed is worried.

GEORGE SEAY, ANNANDALE CAPITAL: The Fed has to cut. The Fed went a bridge too far in December, and they have got to roll it back.

The problem is, Powell stuck his foot in his mouth so many times, that he's going to play the Chinese save face and spread it out a little bit before he starts cutting again. But the economy needs it. The 10-year has already told you he's going to cut because it's dropped about 80 basis points in a matter of months.

CAVUTO: Right. You're talking to a popular trading note that sort of telegraphs how mortgage rates are going to be. So that could be a good underpinning here, right?

SEAY: Absolutely. There's no alternative to stocks in the public markets. Bonds are no alternative.

CAVUTO: On the trade front, we're getting talk -- and you kind of touched on it -- that the U.S. and Mexico are looking to hold talks on this very issue, the better than $300 billion worth of Mexican imports that come in, on which we're going to put a 5 percent tariff anyway.

They're going to be chaired by the vice president, Jackie, on Wednesday.

DEANGELIS: Mm-hmm.

CAVUTO: So how does this all sort out?

DEANGELIS: Well, a lot of folks, at least market watchers, are saying, basically, they think the Mexicans have come here to make some sort of a deal, that they are willing and open. They don't necessarily want to see these tariffs go into place, even if the 5 percent does.

Scott Martin, always good catching up with you, my friend. Thank you.

MARTIN: See you.

CAVUTO: All right, you think the president is having problems with the Mexicans with the latest tariffs against Mexico he's proposing, you should see the grief he's getting from many in his own party.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

SEN. ROB PORTMAN (R-OH): It looks like the statute that he's using to invoke these tariffs, which never have been used before for tariffs, by the way, probably would end up with a vote here in Congress. And that's a bad thing too. Let's not go through that process again.

We already voted wants to disapprove the president on the national security issue of the -- of the national emergency at the border. He then vetoed that. And then it wasn't overridden. Why go through that again?

(END VIDEO CLIP)

CAVUTO: And Rob Portman vows, as do quite a few other Republican senators, Rand Paul, Mitch McConnell, a host of others, that this will not play out well, by all of a sudden using trade as a lever to go after what's the president argues, probably rightly, is going on at the border, and the Mexicans aren't doing anything about it.

But we already have a trade deal with Mexico. And they're concerned that the president is going to ruin the odds of getting that thing ultimately ratified.

Republican pollster Lee Carter is here.

I'm just wondering how big a tempest in a teapot this is.

LEE CARTER, REPUBLICAN POLLSTER: You know, this is Donald Trump. And this is the way that he does things. He negotiates hard and strong. And we all look at it like it's a game of chicken.

And it's terrifying to all of us, because we're looking at what he's actually doing and saying, oh, my gosh, here's the impact of these tariffs. It's going to be terrible.

What ends up happening is, Trump puts something on the table to take it off the table. And we're all reacting.

Now, what should the GOP do as a result? Because the tariffs are not in our best interest as Americans. We look at what might be happening to Chipotle, for example. They say it's going to cost them $15 million if the tariffs go in, that the price of a burrito is going to go up.

If we look at Jeeps, all kinds of things, there's going to be a huge impact.

CAVUTO: I'm worried about the tequila thing. That one worries me.

CARTER: I am very, very worried about the tequila thing.

But I don't know as though it's ever going to become an issue, because when you look at what the president does...

CAVUTO: So it won't come to that?

CARTER: I don't think it's going to come to that.

But I think that the Republican lawmakers have to get out there and say that they oppose this just because it is -- if it does go through, they're going to have to go on record and say, we did oppose this, because it's going to have a huge impact on the American consumer.

CAVUTO: And we have a deal with the Mexicans and the Canadians. The Canadians are saying they're going to go through with the ratification process there, assuming that this will ultimately be passed here.

But this is a big monkey wrench here. And that's, I think, the concern these Republicans are raising. Or is it, like you said, just sort of theater to get what the president wants on the border? After all, the finance minister rushed here. We're learning that talks will ensue tomorrow 3:00-4:00 p.m. at the White House, the vice president overseeing them.

So maybe they get what they want.

CARTER: Let's hope that they get what they want, because, in the end, this could be a disaster for the American consumer.

And I think that we have seen the president do this kind of thing. He did it with China. He's done this kind of thing before. He puts crazy things out there that we're all terrified of. In the end, it's not what happens.

So, hopefully, we end up with a win-win for everybody. But who knows? And I think the Republican lawmakers have to go on record and say, don't do it, because...

CAVUTO: Yes.

Could I ask you now, how is the trade thing polling now? The president's poll numbers have ticked up. I know this is a day-by-day kind of a thing here. He's got undisputed loyalty among Republican voters. So what is your sense now, especially today, where we got the Federal Reserve saying, we have your back, if this really slows things down, and we will cut interest rates?

That's my impression of it at least. What do you think?

CARTER: Right.

What do I think about -- look, I think the president is actually much stronger than everybody likes to say out there. I have seen all kinds of the media covering right now that he is weaker than he has been.

He's not. He's got a very strong base. I don't think that any Democrat that's running right now could beat him today.

CAVUTO: Really?

Who would have the best chance? Everyone talks about Joe Biden, but I'm not so sure he even gets the nomination.

CARTER: Look, I always say at this stage in the game, the person that's going to win is the person you can't keep your eyes off of. It's the one that you just are so enamored with that you have got to know more about.

Joe Biden doesn't do that for people. Donald Trump does. We can't help but look at him and focus and react to him. We're not reacting to Joe Biden. Joe Biden put out -- he's a terrible candidate when he runs. It's very, very sad, because a very likable guy most the time, and then he goes out there and puts himself out there.

He puts this Green New Deal out there, for example. His messaging is terrible. It's boring. It makes you want to snore. And that is a big problem for him.

CAVUTO: Well, that's because you're anti-Green New Deals, maybe. I don't know.

CARTER: I don't know.

CAVUTO: And $1.7 trillion over 10 years.

CARTER: I think that that could be a messaging land mine, if they would just let it be.

Instead of talking about the green part, they should be talking about the jobs and the economy -- economic benefits. That's not what they're doing.

(CROSSTALK)

CAVUTO: But the hard left, they're not pleased with his plan. They said it's too moderate at $1.7 trillion over 10 years.

CARTER: Well, they're all running against each other right now. So let's see how that plays out.

CAVUTO: But, normally, a strong economy would benefit the incumbent.

Are you surprised that the president, with this -- no one could debate the strength of this economy.

CARTER: Nobody could debate that.

CAVUTO: But he's not doing that well. He's fine, don't get me wrong, but what's holding it back? All the other stuff?

CARTER: All the other stuff.

I mean, people can't help but -- you can't separate the person from the policy. You can't separate the personality from the problems.

CAVUTO: Right.

CARTER: And so people have a lot of problems with his personality, even if they're feeling that they're -- that...

CAVUTO: Yes.

CARTER: And it's almost like they're having trouble giving him credit for it. It's like, I can't say I feel better about the economy and it's Trump's.

CAVUTO: Not happening.

CARTER: Yes, not going to happen.

CAVUTO: All right, it's weird.

Lee Carter, great seeing you again.

CARTER: Good to be here.

CAVUTO: Of course, that big powwow with the Mexican finance minister at the White House, all that slated for tomorrow. We will see what happens there.

Here comes "The Five" right now.
