urn:contentItem:5W8C-0B51-DXH2-60G0-00000-00Tariff Battle; Wal-Mart's College Plan; U.S. Tech Giants Facing Probes; Stock Surge; President Trump Continues Great Britain Visit2019-06-04T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:29:02ZLexisNexisYOUR WORLD WITH NEIL CAVUTO4:00 PM ESTLee Carter, Scott Martin, Cathy Areu, Noelle Nikpour, George SeayNEWSInternational060401cb.140Tariff Battle; Wal-Mart's College Plan; U.S. Tech Giants Facing Probes; Stock Surge; President Trump Continues Great Britain VisitDonna Brazile, Kat Timpf, Andrew Napolitano, Jackie DeAngelis, John Roberts, Susan Li, Neil Cavuto

NEIL CAVUTO, FOX NEWS ANCHOR: All right, the royal dinner going on right now as we speak at the Winfield House, the residence of the ambassador, the American ambassador to Great Britain.

The president exchanging the courtesy that the Brits afforded him with a dinner of his own to host the key British players. There is a possibility in a little bit we could be hearing from individual participants, maybe the president a little bit later in the dinner.

But the pool spray that they like to call it of the room is done. And, of course, the feast is on.

But the feast was on at the corner of Wall and Broad? See what I did there. The feast was on the corner of Wall and Broad.

Welcome, everybody. I'm Neil Cavuto.

So let's talk about stocks. Let's talk about the president, because what's going on over here is something that was really reflective of what was going on over there, partly, the president not backing down on his trade fight with Mexico now, amid tensions that are still high with China.

But those two were linked by the Federal Reserve, and the chairman, Jerome Powell, saying that the Central Bank is prepared to act to protect the economy if, in fact, things get much worse on the trade front, in other words, if things slow down.

The markets immediately pounced on that as a sign that the Fed has the president's back and has our back just in case things slip, slide away on the trade front, the Dow up about 511 points today. The Nasdaq, which had entered a correction territory, down about 10 percent, or a little bit more from its highs, coming back today.

We have got a lot going on here. We have got FOX team coverage with John Roberts in London, where the president is not letting Mexico off the hook. We have also got FOX Business Network's Susan Li on a Fed chief who doesn't want to be on the hook.

We begin with John.

Hey, John.

JOHN ROBERTS, FOX NEWS CHIEF WHITE HOUSE CORRESPONDENT: Hey. Good evening to you, Neil.

The stock market didn't seem to care a whole lot about what the president said regarding Mexico. We should point out that one of the guests at that dinner at the ambassador's residence at Winfield House has got an early flight tomorrow morning.

Secretary of State Mike Pompeo will be leaving it first light head back to the United States because he will be leading negotiations with the Mexican delegation in Washington, D.C., to see if they will do something, if they're willing to do something more to stop Central American migrants from moving through Mexico toward the U.S. border.

The president today, seemingly unimpressed with recent Mexican claims that they have stepped up apprehensions and deportations of Central American migrants who are in Mexico illegally, the president suggesting that those tariffs that are scheduled to go into effect on Monday at 5 percent are going to go into effect.

And the president also dismissing some talk about some Republicans in Congress that they may move to block those tariffs before they go into effect. Listen to what the president said earlier today.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

DONALD TRUMP, PRESIDENT OF THE UNITED STATES: I don't think they will do that. I think, if they do, it's foolish. There's nothing more important than borders. I have had tremendous Republican support.

And, as you know, Mexico called. They want to meet. They're going to meet on Wednesday. Secretary Pompeo is going to be at the meeting, along with a few others that are very good at this. And we are going to see if we can do something. But I think it's more likely that the tariffs go on. And we will probably be talking during the time that the tariffs are on and they're going to be paid.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

ROBERTS: You know, one of the big issues that was going on in talks between the United States and Britain, particularly this morning, when the president was sitting down with Theresa May, was Britain's plans to use Huawei equipment made in China as part of its new 5G system.

Originally, Britain wanted to use Huawei equipment in its 5G core, because basically they're selling it for pennies on the dollar against equipment from other countries. And there's a reason for that, many American officials believe, because China wants to get into the core of the new 5G systems because everything that flows through there can be sucked out and sent back to China.

So I'm told by national security officials that they have convinced Britain not to use Huawei in the core. But Britain, not wanting to really upset China, still wanted to use some Huawei equipment. But the president suggesting at the press conference with Theresa May earlier today that they do have an agreement on Huawei, though he wouldn't say exactly what it was.

Listen here.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

TRUMP: We're going to have absolutely an agreement on Huawei and everything else. We have an incredible intelligence relationship and we will be able to work out any differences. I think we're not going to have -- but we did discuss it. I see absolutely no limitations. We have never had limitations.

This is a truly great ally and partner, and we will have no problem with that.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

ROBERTS: And British officials suggest that there is some sort of an agreement. They didn't want to talk to us about the details before it goes to Parliament.

But the president was suggesting that, if the Britain was to use 5G equipment from Huawei in their systems, that that might kind of upset the apple cart in terms of intelligence-sharing with the United States. And that's clearly something that Britain doesn't want to broach -- Neil.

CAVUTO: All right, John Roberts traveling with the president in London right now.

Now, you might hear this back and forth on trade, and now the issues with the Mexicans and the Chinese and the slowdown that could follow. Well, why would start to rise in that environment? Precisely because the Federal Reserve said it has everybody's back in case that does happen.

To Susan Li on that.

Hey, Susan.

SUSAN LI, FOX NEWS CORRESPONDENT: Yes, you're exactly right, Neil, so the Federal Reserve providing cover today, telling the markets if trade wars hurt economic growth, we can adjust and cut interest rates, and that sent the stock market into rally mode.

Wall Street pricing in a near certainty that interest rates will be cut this year. That's close to 100 percent, the probability sitting at 97 percent. Big tech names were the main drags yesterday on concerns they will be broken up or at least investigated over antitrust concerns, coming back today, so recovery for Amazon, Google, parent to Alphabet, as well as, as you see, Apple, Netflix and Microsoft.

And when these heavyweight stocks move, they tend to take the broader markets along with them. Now, we do have the Mexican foreign minister, along with the Mexican economic minister, in Washington, D.C., right now. They are meeting with House Speaker Nancy Pelosi, but the Mexican side have threatened to retaliate if President Trump does go through with these tariffs on all Mexican goods that come into the U.S.

And President Trump did say this morning in that London press conference that tariffs will likely go up. Now, will that impact the U.S. economy? That really depends on how long tariffs stay on and how high they eventually get -- Neil.

CAVUTO: All right, Susan, thank you very, very much.

With the Dow surge today, about 512.5 points, that is the best performance of the year for the Dow on this, after getting just clubbed on concerns about trade.

So what are we really looking at here?

Let's get the read from George Seay of Annandale Capital. He's the CEO there. We have also got Jackie DeAngelis with us, of course, FOX Business Network.

Jackie, a weird reaction, and then you can understand, yes, if rates come down, that will weather this. But obviously the Fed is prepared for something.

JACKIE DEANGELIS, FOX BUSINESS CORRESPONDENT: Well, the Fed changed the game today, Neil, I mean, basically coming out and telling President Trump that he's got their back and that a rate cut is definitely in the cards.

And that's something that investors wanted to hear. They thought it was on the table, but they didn't get the confidence or the language from the Fed that they wanted to hear. Today, that's what they got. So nothing's changed in terms of trade. In fact, the president said, come Monday, those 5 percent tariffs on Mexico will probably go into place.

That's what he told us today. But the market feels more confident that there's support for economic growth and that Jerome Powell is going to step up and do the right thing.

He made two mistakes. Basically, there was a communication mistake at the end of last year. He corrected that. Correcting the policy mistake, as the market sees it, would be implementing a cut.

CAVUTO: Right.

You know, the president criticized the rate hikes, as you know, George, saying that they were a little bit more than was needed. The latest talk is that maybe we could unwind two of the 10 rate hikes we have seen since this tightening cycle started with the former Federal Reserve chief beforehand.

Now I'm wondering where this goes, because you could also interpret from that the Fed is worried.

GEORGE SEAY, ANNANDALE CAPITAL: The Fed has to cut. The Fed went a bridge too far in December, and they have got to roll it back.

The problem is, Powell stuck his foot in his mouth so many times, that he's going to play the Chinese save face and spread it out a little bit before he starts cutting again. But the economy needs it. The 10-year has already told you he's going to cut because it's dropped about 80 basis points in a matter of months.

CAVUTO: Right. You're talking to a popular trading note that sort of telegraphs how mortgage rates are going to be. So that could be a good underpinning here, right?

SEAY: Absolutely. There's no alternative to stocks in the public markets. Bonds are no alternative.

CAVUTO: On the trade front, we're getting talk -- and you kind of touched on it -- that the U.S. and Mexico are looking to hold talks on this very issue, the better than $300 billion worth of Mexican imports that come in, on which we're going to put a 5 percent tariff anyway.

They're going to be chaired by the vice president, Jackie, on Wednesday.

DEANGELIS: Mm-hmm.

CAVUTO: So how does this all sort out?

DEANGELIS: Well, a lot of folks, at least market watchers, are saying, basically, they think the Mexicans have come here to make some sort of a deal, that they are willing and open. They don't necessarily want to see these tariffs go into place, even if the 5 percent does.

Remember, President Trump threatened that it could be 25 percent by October. So the feeling is that the Mexicans have come to the negotiating table. They are ready, willing and able, much more so, for example, than China.

CAVUTO: All right, we forget that a lot of these increases that we would likely see with the tariffs on Mexico would be immediate. In other words, they literally go from country to table in this case or grocery store.

So we would feel that 5 percent hike, but we would start feeling it more got to be more of a hike, right?

SEAY: Absolutely.

And we in Texas are very fond of trade with Mexico. And I thought we learned from the Germans in World War II you don't find a two-front war at one time. So I would like to see us get the Mexican distraction off the table as soon as possible and pivot to China, which is the real problem.

CAVUTO: Do you worry, though, that it also could jeopardize the -- just how we go about future trade relations? We already have a deal with the Mexicans and the Canadians.

It was something that Rob Portman, the senator from Ohio, was concerned about when I talked to him earlier. I don't know if we have that. But he is -- he's worried. He's worried.

Take a look.

No, I apologize.

So, one of the things he had raised was this notion that you are jeopardizing a deal you fought hard to get. And now he's worried that this could leave some pretty muddy waters.

Do you agree?

SEAY: Well, the president's fearless, but he's also reckless and ad hoc. And that's a dangerous way to go about your business.

And I think that's what Senator Portman is getting it. And I think we need to tighten up the process a little more and be a little more methodical about how we lay out U.S. policy. It's a little bit too reflexive and knee-jerk.

CAVUTO: All right.

What do you mean -- Jackie, I was looking at a lot of U.S. companies that were concerned about China moved their operations to Mexico. Guadalajara was a popular location. And the irony now is that they're stuck behind the eight ball again.

DEANGELIS: It is. It is an irony.

And the market basically looked at this and said we had made progress with USMCA, and now we're talking about another tariff here that's not related to trade, per se, but it's related to the border. And it's related to immigration.

Let me give you an example, Neil. If the tariffs on Mexico went up to 25 percent by October, and you still had the 25 percent tariffs on China in place, for automakers, they're going to suffer as result of this because they're bring in the steel and the aluminum.

So a car that's made here, for example, could be almost $2,000 higher. A car that's imported from one of those places could be almost $5,000 higher. So there's going to be an impact on the consumer, on American companies. Somebody is going to have to figure out who's going to absorb it or how they're going to pass it along.

But, again, with Powell stepping up today, the market sort of took a sigh of relief. I will just add one final point, that we have seen the pendulum swing here, so I need to see more than one day of a rally to believe that everybody's comfortable with this.

CAVUTO: Right.

Yes, we forgot the prior snapshots there.

Guys, I want to thank you both very, very much.

All right, you have Google, Amazon, Facebook, and Apple all being targeted right now by the United States government in one way, shape, or form. At first, when I heard about this, I thought it was the Europeans pouncing on these guys. It is us pouncing on these guys -- after this.

CAVUTO: All right, if you think about it, they are some of the biggest names in technology. And right now, in Washington, D.C., they're all targets.

I'm talking about Google and Amazon, Facebook and Apple, which, for various reasons, have the attention of the Justice Department, the Federal Trade Commission, on everything from privacy violations to simply getting too big for their britches.

But is there a legal case to be made for breaking them up, or, worse, really, really breaking them up and giving them grief?

Judge Andrew Napolitano on all of that.

What do you think?

ANDREW NAPOLITANO, FOX NEWS JUDICIAL ANALYST: Well, it's very unusual, Neil, for the government to announce an investigation, an antitrust investigation, before it actually starts one.

Usually, it starts very quietly. It begins looking at public documents, and then it subpoenas documents behind the public documents. But, for some reason, this Justice Department, with a president -- a pro-business president, is doing something that even the Obama Justice Department never did, which is basically saying to those four tech giants, are you guys so big that you can't be trusted, and it's time for us, the government, to regulate you?

Now, what are they looking for? They're probably looking for predatory behavior. That is behavior that elbows out competition, so charging different price levels, punishing a customer because the customer also sells to somebody who doesn't sell through you.

All of that is potentially antitrust activity, providing -- that's the bottom line for all but one antitrust-type actions -- providing the consumer is hurt. So if there's predatory activity, if they're pricing themselves so low that their competition dies, but the consumer benefits from that by getting the same service at a lesser cost, the government...

CAVUTO: Right, or for free.

NAPOLITANO: Correct. The government won't get involved.

The only time they don't have to prove that the consumer was harmed is price-fixing, if there's an actual agreement between them to fix prices. These four don't basically compete against each other. They're each in different fields.

So I don't think price-fixing is the goal here.

CAVUTO: But I'm old enough to remember when the government was going after Netscape, right?

NAPOLITANO: Yes.

CAVUTO: Remember, you would separate your browser from your Internet product. Netscape is now long gone.

And it was market forces that made it go long gone, not scrutiny, government scrutiny.

And I'm just wondering if the markets can't correct whatever they're talking about. Or is the fear, they have got to address this because they will get so big for their britches, they can't be reined in?

NAPOLITANO: Here's the -- here's the government's argument. I don't necessarily buy this, but here's the government's argument.

CAVUTO: Right.

NAPOLITANO: You are so big and so powerful, and you have so many customers, that the barriers to entry, the cost of competing with you is nearly impossible to amass. So nobody can effectively compete with you. Therefore, you...

CAVUTO: Well, that was the Amazon argument, right?

The legal reasoning hinged on highly technical points about the tax status of Google's French operations, which had been raided months earlier by police. At first, it looked as if the French government would tamely accept this. But, in a surprise move reflecting widespread frustration, the new Macron government came up with a bold riposte early in September. Finance minister Bruno Le Maire announced that Paris and Berlin were mounting a joint offensive to tax Internet giants, by in future taxing the likes of Amazon, Google and Facebook on their massive revenues rather than the meager profits they declared. There has long been confusion among governments trying to wring more tax out of recalcitrant international corporates.

FULL TEXT

Attempts to stamp out global tax avoidance are being undermined by countries negotiating lowtax sweetheart deals. How should the system be cleaned up?

Paris-based court in July ruled against the French government and in favour of Google declaring that the tech titan did not have to pay $ubn in back taxes made by channelling sales through Ireland. The legal reasoning hinged on highly technical points about the tax status of Google's French operations, which had been raided months earlier by police.

At first, it looked as if the French government would tamely accept this. But, in a surprise move reflecting widespread frustration, the new Macron government came up with a bold riposte early in September.

Finance minister Bruno Le Maire announced that Paris and Berlin were mounting a joint offensive to tax internet giants, by in future taxing the likes of Amazon, Google and Facebook on their massive revenues rather than the meagre profits they declared.

The snag is that, under EU treaties, tax measures require all members to back change, hence the question becomes whether countries such as Luxembourg and Ireland with low-tax regimes favouring the behemoths would be forced to buckle and shift policy.

There has long been confusion among governments trying to wring more tax out of recalcitrant international corporates. States are united in their desire to remedy a situation where the world's biggest companies get away with paying close to zero taxes, thereby eroding their countries' fragile tax bases. However, they also compete with each other to offer firms favourable tax treatments, disagree about how best to make progress and are mired in their own tax legislation, a thicket of fiendishly complex and sometimes obsolete tax rules that are wide open to abuse. With no one contemplating upending the entire global tax regulations and starting afresh, meaningful reform has proved slow and difficult.

According to the European Commission, between €5obn and €7obn a year is lost by EU states through tax avoidance. The battle over international tax is being fought on the one side by states, operating individually and through multilateral organisations, notably the EU, the OECD and G20 countries and the UN. On the other side are corporates backed by legions of professional tax specialists; the latter, who sometime advise governments too, have created an industry seeking out loopholes, exemptions and other means to minimise tax bills. Meanwhile in the UK, an All-Party Parliamentary Group on Responsible Tax has been set up. The chair, veteran MP Margaret Hodge, describes this as a "unique forum" bringing together people with views from across the spectrum.

Looking on are the public whose growing ire against big companies' failure to contribute is reportedly one of the wellsprings of populism. And the debate is regularly jolted by wholesale leaks, such as the Panama Papers, which reveal the eye-popping scale of dealings through shell companies and other devices.

The framework of international tax law dates back to early last century; debate over how multinational companies use the system is doubtless as old. One perennial problem has been the treatment for tax purposes of cross-border activities within a company, so-called transfer pricing. For example, what would be the market "price" for a UK subsidiary to pay for an engine part design pioneered by its parent car company in Detroit if the two were not connected? And how do you prevent manipulation of the figures simply to minimise the tax liability?

With the arrival of the digital economy in the past 20 years, these issues have become exacerbated, with "digitalisation posing serious challenges to the existing international tax framework", according to Mannheim University's Marcel Olbert and Christoph Spengel, writing in World Tax Journal. Unlike traditional bricks and mortar businesses, the digital world tends to operate seamlessly across borders and relies to an unprecedented extent on intangibles such as technical knowledge or databases. If you want to put a couple of items in your Amazon basket, you can do so even if you are on a safari trip to South Africa.

"Taxation of e-commerce is problematic due to anonymity, difficulty in determining the amount of tax, lack of paper trails, tax havens, companies incurring liability in multiple countries and tax administrations' lack of capacity," says Eli Hadzhieva of think-tank Dialogue for Europe, in a paper issued by the European Parliament.

A specific digital problem is that a standard internet model is to give away a service (such as internet searching) while deriving revenues from the extensive data provided for free by users, which makes it hard to determine in which tax jurisdiction value is created.

Critics argue that every transnational business relies on the activities of the state, not least for the enforcement of their contracts. Yet they can make themselves virtually stateless. (When one told Margaret Hodge two years ago that it would be moving its headquarters to the UK, it admitted shamefacedly that this would create fewer than a dozen jobs.)

In addition, there are at least two issues associated particularly with Big Tech. First, owing largely to so-called network effects, the tech industry tends towards monopoly, with a few massive players such as Amazon, Facebook and Google dwarfing their competitors. Second, these companies are adept at exploiting opportunities to get around regulations in a way not directly related to their digital origins. So Uber's business model relies not simply on its network and slick apps, but also on its treatment of drivers as self-employed, which means the company is exempt from providing them with many employee benefits. Similarly, up to one-third of the price gap between Airbnb and hotel rooms is due to the more lenient tax treatment.

In international tax matters, the devil is in the most granular detail. However, some general moves would improve matters. One is to increase transparency. Clearer rules on where value is created and tighter rules defining where a business operates would also help.

Aside from the EU - where the new French-led initiative has shaken things up - the most active efforts to reform the international system have been by the OECD and G20 countries. While their remit has been far broader than the EU's, they have painstakingly built a consensus. In 2012, the G20 tasked the OECD to develop an action plan, which it duly did the following year. Its base erosion and profit sharing (BEPS) package, designed to be implemented by governments domestically and through tax treaty, was agreed in 2015. Featured among the 15 actions were mandatory disclosure rules, guidelines on permanent establishment (defining where a firm is resident) and addressing the tax challenges of the digital economy.

Many commentators have urged that specific measures should be created for the mighty tech sector. But this idea has lost favour. Olbert explains: "Some individual nations have enacted tax laws targeting digital transactions. Yet the OECD/G20 and EU members share the view that a special tax regime is neither feasible nor effective."

As OECD tax expert Pascal Saint-Amans says: "The findings are that there is no such thing as digital companies rather than digitalisation of the economy. There may not therefore be a solution for the digital economy but we will need to draw on features of the digital economy when we revise the system."

The OECD and G20 have given countries another three years to negotiate, with an interim report by the OECD taskforce due next spring. The OECD is also considering expanding the definition of permanent establishment and developing an interim measure called alternative tax on e-sales.

Olbert adds: "Everyone is aware of the need for action. However, little information is published as there are no binding official statements on whether the tax principles will be revised to meet the challenges of the digital economy."

Put simply, countries are not progressing determinedly with a common purpose towards tax reform. While they are lending their weight to the OECD plans, they simultaneously have an eye out for their own narrow interests. Ireland exploited the notorious double Irish tax device, which allowed companies to take advantage of its low tax jurisdiction, until 2015, and Luxembourg has favourable rules, which explain why so many routine internet transactions are charged there.

Countries famously negotiate sweetheart deals with big corporates and are also competing over tax rates and making it easy to set up business. As Rita Cunha, policy researcher for the APPG on Responsible Tax at the Policy Institute at King's College London, explains: "Countries are making progress tackling BEPS but it is slow. Some countries are a little bit half-hearted. Everyone seems to be competing to attract investment. So there is always a tension there. I don't think that will disappear - I think of it as a game."

Asked if the UK is beyond reproach, Hodge declares flatly: "No." She says: "Governments are facing both ways. The UK could very easily use its powers over our overseas territories and crown dependencies to force strong transparency so you know who owns what. These are really important jurisdictions that facilitate aggressive tax avoidance and evasion, and money laundering." And she characterises the prime minister's fear of offending any of these jurisdictions as "pathetic".

So what of Brexit? It surely will be tempting for the UK, as it scours the world for valuable trade deals, to start to offer tempting tax treatments once it is no longer bound by EU rules from 2019, especially if the EU tightens its rules. Hodge thinks this - the "Singapore option" - is possible but unlikely. Apart from anything else, she believes the UK would face swift retaliation from the remainder of the EU and that the Treasury would be reluctant to forego the revenue. "I think they are crying wolf, but I may have to change my mind on that," she admits.

Behind the debate about international tax lies one fundamental unanswered question: do corporates face a moral duty in paying tax or is it rather simply a matter of adhering to the law and rules?

Unsurprisingly, Hodge insists there is a moral dimension. Paying a fair proportion of taxes chimes with companies' now ubiquitous corporate social responsibility programmes, for example. And there is a more pragmatic reason: failing to be seen to pay your fair share can make a company's reputation toxic, especially among the young.

She has another argument too. "It will always be impossible to devise a tax system without ambiguity. No system can be black and white in every instance."

So if the tax system is not to become an interminable game where the corporates simply stay one jump ahead of the tax authorities as they close one loophole after another, there has to be some moral component.

It's a persuasive argument. But, as Hodge concedes, she has never met a corporate representative or tax adviser who agrees with her. ?

urn:contentItem:5RRK-N6N1-DY4X-T01R-00000-00Tax Break Meant to Attract Intellectual Property Could See WTO Challenge2018-02-25T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:29:02ZLexisNexisTax Break Meant to Attract Intellectual Property Could See WTO ChallengeCasey Wooten

One part of last year s tax overhaul meant to lure back overseas profits from big tech and pharmaceutical companies could be headed for a showdown in the World Trade Organization, analysts say. And a ruling against the U.S. may have far-reaching implications on both tax and trade policy.

It s known as the Foreign-Derived Intangible Income provision, or FDII. The provision, in theory, would provide a low tax rate for U.S. companies with overseas profits from intangible assets such as patents, licenses, or trademarks. It s an incentive for multinationals that rely on easily transferable intellectual property, like Apple, Inc., to locate their assets and profits in the U.S. rather than a low-tax jurisdiction or tax haven.

But the new tax break has run afoul of European trade ministers who say it amounts to a subsidy on exports under WTO rules. The tax bill is only a few months old, but it has led many to prepare for a challenge from the international trade regulator and to consider how Congress and the administration would react.

If I was a betting man and I don t bet on anything, but this would be one bet that I would take that it s almost certain that a challenge is going to come, said Douglas Stransky, a tax partner at Sullivan & Worcester in Boston.

That feeling among international tax professionals stems from the fact that the European Union has a successful history of challenging similar U.S. tax provisions going back three decades.

Export provisions like the FDII have been enacted, and then scrapped, because of challenges in international trade bodies. It started in 1971 with the Domestic International Sales Corporation, or DISC, export-tax benefit, then came the Foreign Sales Corporation in 1984, and then an extraterritorial-income-exclusion provision, or ETI, in 2000.

Those provisions met resistance from U.S. trade partners, and Congress replaced one with another successive version. In 2004, Congress eliminated the ETI, replacing it with a deduction for domestic manufacturers without running afoul of the WTO because it wasn t contingent on exports. Congress repealed that tax break, known as Section 199, in last year s tax-code overhaul.

The new provision would offer U.S.-based C-corporations an effective tax rate of 13.125 percent until 2025 on foreign royalties from assets like patents, licenses, and trademarks. After 2025, the rate rises to 16.4 percent. That s still a big break, considering that companies previously would have had to pay the full corporate tax rate, which currently sits at 21 percent, down from 35 percent before the tax overhaul.

The FDII tax break comes as countries on both sides of the Atlantic go through major changes in their international tax policy. Ireland, once a popular jurisdiction for multinational tech and pharmaceutical companies to park their foreign subsidiaries, is set in 2020 to scrap its so-called double-Irish tax maneuver, which allowed companies to lower their taxable income by setting up an Irish-registered entity in a tax haven that housed their intellectual property and a second Irish-based company that licensed those assets.

But even before Congress passed the tax bill in December, European trade ministers were already up in arms over the provision. Five European officials sent a letter to Treasury Secretary Steven Mnuchin arguing that the bill s treatment of international intangible income was an export subsidy that violated WTO rules.

The design of the regime is notably different from accepted IP regimes by providing a deduction for income derived from intangible assets other than patents and copyright software, such as branding, market power, and market-related intangibles, the letter said.

Stransky said the U.S. could argue that since the provision covers only C-corporations, not other entities like S-corporations and partnerships, its effect is limited. More so, foreign companies could always establish a U.S. subsidiary and take advantage of the tax break, he said.

An aide to House Ways and Means Committee Chairman Kevin Brady said in an email that the committee is confident the tax provisions are compatible with international tax rules and standards.

But if European officials lodge a complaint and the WTO agrees, Congress and the administration would have to make a choice about how to react. In the past, when the U.S. lost fights over the export provisions, Congress simply repealed them. But the Trump administration may not react the same way as the Bush administration and the Bush-era Congress did with the ETI, for example.

If a decision comes down after President Trump leaves office, or if there is a Democratic majority in Congress, the calculus may change. Democrats may wish to simply repeal the provision, though that may pose its own problems as it could remove the incentive for companies to keep intellectual property in the country, again raising the spectre of multinationals shifting profits overseas.

The WTO dispute-settlement body may allow retaliatory tariffs on some U.S. goods, but the Trump administration may just accept that cost and continue implementing the tax break. A more extreme option would be for the administration to exit the WTO a distinct possibility, Stransky said.

At the end of the day, if it s a choice between tax cuts and the tariffs, I think that tax cuts would win, he said.

Reuven Avi-Yonah, a professor at the University of Michigan Law School and director of the school s International Tax LLM Program, has written on this scenario in a January academic paper .

Given the prevailing views on economic sovereignty in the Trump administration and in certain corners of Congress, the willingness of the GOP congressional majorities to defy the WTO stands in stark opposition to the way the GOP behaved in 2004. This relatively obscure tax issue could have very troubling long-term implications, Avi-Yonah wrote.

urn:contentItem:5PVV-2TN1-JBG3-619T-00000-00Tax Day Is Finally Here (or So We Think): DealBook Briefing2017-11-02T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:29:02ZLexisNexisBUSINESSdealbookTax Day Is Finally Here (or So We Think): DealBook BriefingANDREW ROSS SORKIN, MICHAEL J. de la MERCED and AMIE TSANG

House Republicans are expected to unveil their long-awaited tax overhaul, but questions remain about how the proposed changes would be financed.

Good Thursday morning from Andrew Ross Sorkin in New York and Michael J. de la Merced and Amie Tsang in London. We’re watching the widening fallout from sexual misconduct accusations and V.C.s spending less money in trying to find the next Uber. More on those in a minute. (And congrats to the Houston Astros for finally winning the World Series.)

Tell us what you think: We’ve put together a survey about the economy, business and public policy with our friends at Morning Consult. Take it here.

A reminder: DealBook’s sixth annual conference, Playing for the Long Term, takes place on Nov. 9. Want to join us? Apply to participate here.

Who’s going to pay for tax cuts?

Today, we’re supposed to finally see House Republicans’ vision of what a tax code change would look like (even if it is unlikely to bear the name President Trump is said to prefer, the “Cut Cut Cut Act”). The bill will include a permanent cut of the corporate tax rate to 20 percent and a phased-in repeal of the estate tax, according to   Axios.

But the question of how the bill would be financed remains unanswered. “Some industry groups familiar with the negotiations said the remaining shortfall was in the hundreds of billions of dollars,” according to The NYT.

Among the groups that are expected to pay more, according to Politico: private colleges, charities, companies that provide meals to employees and insurers.

The rollout: Gary Cohn will deliver a midday speech to the Economic Club of Washington, while Steven Mnuchin will speak at the International Franchise Association conference in Los Angeles.

Potential stumbling blocks

A big one, according to Axios, is the treatment of pass-through businesses, which include partnerships like real estate trusts as well as small businesses:

Some influential Republican House members are saying final language on the tax bill’s treatment of those situations will disadvantage some small firms and could imperil G.O.P. support for the plan. “This is supposed to be a simplification. It’s not,” a House G.O.P. member told me. “It’s going to be the most explosive thing once members hear about it.”

Representative Tom MacArthur of New Jersey and other Republicans from high-tax states are still pressing to maintain healthy deductions for state and local taxes, according to The NYT.

Homebuilders have already signaled that they will oppose the bill because it would effectively reduce the home mortgage interest deduction.

And Representative Mark Meadows of North Carolina, the leader of the House Freedom Caucus, has unfavorably compared the secretive talks over the tax bill to the efforts to overhaul health care, according to Politico:

“Anything that gets done in a cloak of secrecy is certainly not what an open and deliberative body should do.”

Critics’ corner

The bill “is a tacit admission of something the rest of the world has already concluded: It’s better to tax people than capital,” writes Greg Ip of The WSJ.

Elsewhere in Washington

The president has revived a feud with a fellow native New Yorker, the Senate minority leader, Chuck Schumer, in the wake of the terrorist attack in Lower Manhattan that killed eight people. (Politico)

Apple, IBM and Google were among the tech companies that signed a legal brief challenging the White House’s efforts to end the Deferred Action for Childhood Arrivals immigration program. (Axios)

Are tech giants stepping up their response to public criticism?

If lawmakers’ questions for the top lawyers at Facebook, Google and Twitter on Wednesday were a clue, tech giants will continue to face heightened scrutiny from Washington and beyond.

Senator Dianne Feinstein of California: “I must say, I don’t think you get it.”

Senator Angus King of Maine: “I’m disappointed that you’re here, and not your C.E.O.s.”

Revelations about tech companies’ actions before the 2016 elections don’t help those companies’ cause. Lawmakers made public some of the political ads that Russian entities bought on social media. Twitter offered 15 percent of its election-related ad inventory to the Russian television network RT, according to   BuzzFeed.

And Britain’s elections watchdog has begun an inquiry into whether Russia used social media to interfere with last year’s “Brexit” referendum, according to The Times of London.

Tech companies’ response to the interference — and the power their size affords them in general — weighed heavily on lawmakers’ minds.

But there are signs that tech titans are recognizing that they must do more to appease Congress and the public. During a call to discuss Facebook’s latest blockbuster quarterly earnings, Mark Zuckerberg said:

“I’ve directed our teams to invest so much in security on top of the other investments we’re making that it will significantly impact our profitability going forward. And I wanted our investors to hear that directly from me. I believe this will make our society stronger and, in doing so, will be good for all of us over the long term.”

And Tim Cook of Apple told NBC News:

“I think they learned along the way a lot. And, you know, I think it’s best to ask them if they projected it or not. I don’t believe that the big issue are ads from foreign government. I believe that’s, like, 0.1 percent of the issue. The bigger issue is that some of these tools are used to divide people, to manipulate people.”

How Farhad Manjoo learned to stop worrying and love big tech

He asks in his latest NYT column: “The tech giants are too big. But what if that’s not so bad?”

‘He’s boring, but he’s to the point.’

That’s what the Jeffries chief economist Ward McCarthy wrote of Jerome Powell, above, whose nomination as the next Federal Reserve chairman is expected to be announced at 3 p.m. today.

What do other economists think of a Powell Fed?

“He represents a bit of the continuation of the status quo without being named Yellen,” said Gennadiy Goldberg, an interest-rate strategist at TD Securities. (Bloomberg)

“You get, broadly speaking, continuity of Yellen’s careful and relatively dovish approach to monetary policy, but with somebody who is a card-carrying Republican,” said Krishna Guha, vice chairman at Evercore ISI and a former New York Fed official. (WSJ)

More macroeconomic news

The Fed left its benchmark interest rate unchanged but suggested that a rate increase would be coming next month. (NYT)

The Bank of England is expected to raise its benchmark interest rate for the first time in more than a decade. (WSJ)

The rise and fall of Gary Cohn, also-ran for the Fed chairmanship. (Politico)

The fallout from sexual misconduct accusations widens.

And it has spread well beyond Harvey Weinstein.

Warner Brothers severed ties with the producer and director Brett Rattner after The L.A. Times spoke with six women who accused him of harassment and assault.

In Britain, Defense Minister Michael Fallon resigned over allegations about his past conduct, amid a growing outcry over claims of sexual harassment or inappropriate behavior by politicians. (NYT)

Netflix and Media Rights Capital halted work on the sixth and final season of “House of Cards” after an actor said that Kevin Spacey made an unwanted sexual advance on him when he was a 14-year-old in the 1980s. Mr. Spacey is now seeking “evaluation and treatment.” (People)

Michael Oreskes, the head of NPR’s news division and a former editor at The NYT, stepped down after being accused of sexually harassing women. (NPR)

A woman who has accused Mr. Trump of unwanted sexual advances is pressing forward with a defamation lawsuit in New York State Supreme Court. (NYT)

The accusations have prompted anxiety among men and companies. From The Hollywood Reporter:

”We all wake up now thinking, ‘What’s next? Who’s next?’” says one network public relations chief.

Investors are spending less time hunting the next Uber.

But venture capital firms are putting more money into the deals they make.

Here’s what’s happening, courtesy of data that Thomson Reuters gave to us first: American V.C. firms invested $17.6 billion in 950 transactions during the third quarter of this year. That is a 5 percent increase in dollars invested but a 7 percent drop in the number of deals — and in fact is the lowest number of deals in a quarter since the beginning of 2012. But it was also the strongest quarter for venture dollars invested since the second quarter of 2015.

What that means: V.C.s are being more conservative about new ventures, even as they invest more. (Thomson Reuters also found that American V.C.s raised $4.4 billion during the quarter, setting a four-year low for fund-raising in a quarter.)

A bit of Silicon Valley humor

“When in San Francisco, I visit the Valley to watch unicorns prance with angels. They talk merrily about rounds and rounds of seeds.” (New Yorker)

Meet Goldman Sachs, purveyor of dad jokes.

From an event that Goldman hosted for its personal lending arm, Marcus, according to Olivia Oran of Reuters:

The Speed Read

M. & A.

Permira said it would buy the corporate finance adviser Duff & Phelps for $1.75 billion from a group that includes Carlyle. (WSJ)

Qualcomm said its $38 billion buyout of NXP could take until early next year to complete, after European antitrust regulators extended their review of the deal. (FT)

Hudson’s Bay Company said it had received an unsolicited offer from Signa Holding, an Austrian investment company, for its German department store chain, Galeria Kaufhof, but that the $3.5 billion bid was incomplete and lacked financing. (WSJ)

Policy and Legal

Muddy Waters Capital has filed a petition in New York State Supreme Court seeking to make Google identify the people behind two email addresses. It says they were used deceptively to solicit information about one of its investment campaigns. (FT)

Celebrities who promote coin offerings may be violating several laws, including antifraud regulations and rules that govern investment brokers, the S.E.C. said in a statement Wednesday afternoon. (NYT)

WPP has started proceedings in Japan against its long-term partner there, Asatsu DK. They clashed after Bain Capital made a bid for the Japanese company. (FT)

Sayfullo Saipov, the suspect in the New York terrorist attack, had passed a background check and driven more then 1,400 times for Uber in the past six months, a reflection of how difficult it is to screen for potentially criminal behavior. (USA Today)

Banks and Banking

Credit Suisse hasn’t been immune to the trading slump, but Tidjane Thiam’s pivot to wealth management has propelled assets under management to a record level. (Bloomberg)

Private Capital (P.E. and V.C.)

Price is still a stumbling block for SoftBank’s proposed Uber investment — shareholders are insisting on a valuation greater than the $50 billion under discussion, according to people with knowledge of the process. (Recode)

Money Managers

A series of deals by top executives at Guggenheim Partners has set off concerns over possible favoritism and self-dealing from its internal compliance, auditing and investment teams. (FT)

Business and Economy

Some analysts worry that the iPhone X, which starts at $1,000, could stunt holiday spending for sellers of clothing and other items. (WSJ)

Tesla is hamstrung on the most basic part of the car business, getting vehicles built on time, and Elon Musk has been trying to calm investors. (NYT)

Berkshire Hathaway’s insurance subsidiaries have yielded billions of investment dollars for Warren Buffett. That may change in the third quarter after Hurricanes Harvey and Irma. (Bloomberg)

Sales of Papa John’s pizza have suffered because of national anthem protests in the National Football League, the company’s founder said. (Sports Illustrated)

Emmanuel Macron is going after France’s wealth tax, which has been sacrosanct since it was created in 1982, leading to accusations that he is the “president of the rich.” (NYT)

Follow Andrew Ross Sorkin @andrewrsorkin, Michael J. de la Merced @m_delamerced and Amie Tsang @amietsang on Twitter.
